I'll climb up the steep of the hill,</br>Or traverse the path of the field,</br>Incline to the curve of the rill,</br>By verdure's thick mantle conceal'd;</br>Shall gales of ambrosia invite,</br>And nature unnotic'd remain?</br>O Solitude, maid of delight!</br>I follow thy steps to the plain.

From thence to the Park let me rove,</br>There Solitude commune with thee,</br>In silence thy beauties approve</br>'Neath the shade of yon towering tree:</br>There, free from all faction and strife,</br>Reposed by they peaceable pow'r,</br>Conceal'd from the tempest of life,</br>Lie hush'd in Ttanquility's bow'r.

But can I again resurvey</br>Those landscapes, Arcadian in view,</br>Where bright as the dawn of the day</br>The voice of soft pleasure I knew?</br>Where truth in the shape of my fair,</br>Enchanted my time with her smile:</br>Her absence my tears shall declare,</br>Express my sensations and toil.

The ravishing touch of her lute</br>Wak'd echo arise from her cell,</br>Sylvanus stood pensive and mute,</br>The satyrs danc'd over the dell;</br>Brown Ceres repair'd to the plain,</br>Her temples with wheat-ears bedeck'd,</br>And Venus, each grace in her train,</br>Came forward with conscious respect.

When Phebe, the pale lamp of night,</br>Purloin'd from Endymion's bed,</br>As oft with transporting delight</br>In passion to Delia I fled:</br>And when from her clover repose</br>The lark brav'd the orient skies,</br>As oft, thou dear cause of my woes,</br>I bask'd in the beams of thy eyes.

But now I no longer can mark</br>Of solitude all the still haunts,</br>Unnoted the deer in the park,</br>Unheard what the nightingale chaunts.</br>On pinions of plaint I reveal</br>To zephyrs that flutter along,</br>Or pour all the sorrows I feel</br>Unmeasur'd in pastoral song.

But pleasures more lasting I greet;</br>O find me some verdure-roof'd shade,</br>Some lonely sequester'd retreat</br>Thy hand, contemplation, has made.</br>Where glides without murmurs the stream,</br>Adown by an antiquate pile,</br>Where pines, thick resisting his beam,</br>Forbid the sun's splendours to smile.

Or where with loud cadence the wave,</br>Near columns disparted by time,</br>By sadness instructed to rave,</br>I'll pour lamentation in rhime.</br>Ah, no!  may my flocks feed no more</br>While Medway, with serpentine sweep,</br>Festivity deals to the shore,</br>While Naiads their citadel keep.

My ewes their fresh pasture refuse,</br>In autumn forget for to breed,</br>Aurora refresh not with dews,</br>The rain ne'er replenish the mead;</br>My hops be all blacken'd with blast,</br>The dolphin cloud over my beans;</br>If all the sharp slights that are past</br>My heart from its tenderness weans.

Ah, no!  can I ever forget</br>When Philomel burden'd each bough,</br>To spring as discharging her debt,</br>She measur'd my sighs by her woe.</br>I stood like the statue of grief,</br>The shade of the hawthorn within,</br>Could waterfalls bring me relief?</br>No, I bade them relinquish their din.

Ye warblers your madrigals cease,</br>Insipid's music of spring:</br>To me would you offer some peace,</br>Forbear any longer to sing.</br>When thus, as a retrospect thought,</br>Ideas had strove to impart,</br>Yet fancy's dear image had brought</br>In vision her charms to my heart;

Behold in the shade of the beech,</br>In all the sweet May of her prime,</br>As far as the eye's distant reach,</br>Walk'd Delia the queen of my rhime;</br>To meet with her swain did she haste,</br>Approach on the wings of the dove;</br>Can mem'ry by time be defac'd?</br>The Park was the compact of love.</br>
